isis.stitle: New Vehicle Processing Manual - Undecking and Storage - UNDECKING AND STORAGE - VEHICLE STORAGE

svcprocinfo.para: The Dealer is responsible for adequate storage and protection of new vehicles, whether they are on Dealer premises or elsewhere. Check current procedures against the following recommendations, and correct any conditions creating unnecessary expense and/or preventable customer dissatisfaction.

When vehicles are delivered directly to a contracted body manufacturer, the Dealer should arrange with the contracted firm for proper vehicle storage and maintenance. We recommend sending a copy of these procedures to the body manufacturer.

note.para: Losses occurring to a unit while it is in storage will not be considered for reimbursement.

svcsubproc.title: Storage Duration - Two Months Or Less
svcsubproc.para: Because you cannot accurately predict how long vehicles will remain in inventory, use at least the following minimum precautions on every unit to prevent deterioration:

step1.para: Remove the protective covering from exposed bright metal components (e.g., polished fuel tanks).
Wash vehicles as necessary. ALWAYS wash vehicles delivered during winter months because of exposure to road salt.

note.para: Washing Instructions - Wash the vehicle with warm water and mild soap, then wipe wet surfaces with a chamois or soft cloth. DO NOT use hot water or strong soaps or detergents. DO NOT wash the vehicle in direct sun, or when the sheet metal is hot to the touch, because this will streak the finish. DO NOT wipe dirt off dry surfaces, because this will scratch the finish.

step1.para: Inspect painted surfaces; touch up all exposed primed or raw metal areas to prevent rust.
Apply a thick coat of wax to prevent discoloration from the elements; wax all chrome and stainless steel metal parts.
Check the radiator coolant for proper level and adequate freeze protection (-20°F is standard for medium duty models and bus chassis, -40°F is standard for heavy duty models).
Cover open ends of vertical exhaust stack(s).

Check state of charge eye in batteries. If any one of the batteries has a dark state of charge indication, charge all batteries. If the eyes of all batteries are green, batteries are charged. If batteries do not have an indicator eye, re-charge if open circuit voltage is below 12.6 volts.

note.para: The majority of batteries now provided in International vehicles are equipped with a "charge indicator eye." If the eye is green, the battery is charged and is in satisfactory condition to deliver to the customer. If the eye is dark, the battery is discharged and must be charged prior to delivery to the customer. If the eye is clear, it means that the electrolyte level is low and the battery must be replaced. A low electrolyte level is normally the result of a broken case or years of usage; it will not be normally seen on new vehicles.

step1.para: On 3000 Models and Stripped Chassis, ensure the protective shipping cover (e.g., horn button cover, shift lever cover, instrument cluster cover, etc.) is properly in place.

svcsubproc.title: Storage Duration - Over Two Months
svcsubproc.para: Units in storage two months or longer require the following procedures:

step1.para: Visually check that tires are inflated and remove vertical exhaust stack covers.

Start and run the vehicle at fast idle until it attains operating temperature. To remove surface charge from the battery, built up from previous start-ups and short idle periods, operate the heater and/or air conditioner and other accessories for a few minutes, and turn on the headlights.

Check state of charge eye in batteries. If any one of the batteries has a dark state of charge indication, charge all batteries. If the eyes of all batteries are green, batteries are charged. If batteries do not have an indicator eye, re-charge if open circuit voltage is below 12.6 volts.
Drive the vehicle a short distance. Shift the transmission in various ranges; engage and disengage the clutch and parking brake; apply and release the service and parking brake systems.
Visually check tire inflation.
Turn off the heater and/or air conditioner and any other accessories; shut off the headlights. Park the vehicle and shut off the engine.
Disconnect battery ground cables to prevent accidental starting, or parasitic electrical loads from discharging the battery; re-cover the vertical exhaust stack(s).
Drain air brake reservoirs and close the drain cocks.

note.para: After every 30 additional days of storage, perform Items 1 through 8.

svcsubproc.para: Perform the following procedures as required to maintain stored vehicles in prime condition:

step1.para: Wash vehicles as necessary (see Washing Instructions).
Inspect painted surfaces; touch up all exposed primed or raw metal areas to prevent rust.
Apply a thick coat of wax to prevent discoloration from the elements; wax all chrome and stainless steel metal parts.

note.para: When vehicles are stored outside, particularly in coastal areas (salt water and high humidity atmosphere), or other areas of corrosive environment, paint and bright metal may require frequent washing and waxing to prevent deterioration. Determining washing frequency is the Dealer's responsibility.

For vehicles exposed to ultraviolet rays of the sun, apply a coating of Bon-Ami, or similar product, to the inside surfaces of the windshield and windows, to shade the interior and prevent fading the interior trim.

step1.para: Check state of charge eye in batteries. If any one of the batteries has a dark state of charge indication, charge all batteries. If batteries do not have an indicator eye, re-charge if open circuit voltage is below 12.6 volts.
Check the radiator coolant for proper level and adequate freeze protection.
Lubricate all exposed transmission, auxiliary transmission and PTO shift rails.

note.para: On Models 3000 and Stripped Chassis, ensure the protective shipping cover; e.g., horn button cover, shift lever cover, instrument cluster cover, etc. is properly in place.

item.para: Whenever possible, store vehicles indoors, protected from sunlight, in a dry, well ventilated area. If indoor storage is not available, select storage lots to eliminate conditions that cause deterioration.
Park away from transformers and/or electrical motors, because when the protective wax in tire compound cracks, ozone in the air attacks the exposed areas.
Park away from trees, high weeds and/or grass to prevent damage from tree or weed sap, and to minimize bird and insect stains.
Park away from railroad tracks, paint shops, smoky industrial areas, and locations of possible road splash contact.
If a vehicle is parked on an incline, block the wheels.
